DOC.HEAD: No Prosecution, Discipline in Rep. Gray Leak Case
Eds: SUBS last graf with two grafs to give Gray comment
DOC.TEXT: Attorney General Dick Thornburgh said Friday he has decided against prosecution or disciplinary action over a news leak about a Pennsylvania Congressman because the department can't identify the leaker. In a letter to Sen. Joseph Biden, D-Del., chairman of the Senate Judiciary Committee, Thornburgh said investigators had been ``unable to identify with certainy the original source'' of unauthorized disclosures to CBS reporter Rita Braver about the office of Rep. William H. Gray III, D-Pa. Thornburgh said the investigators also told him that ``the nature of the confirmations alleged to have been forthcoming to Ms. Braver'' were ``uncertain.'' Consequently, he said, the investigators told him that ``it would be futile and impossible to pursue a prosecution based on the available evidence.'' ``Therefore, I have accepted the recommendation of the investigators and prosecutors that this matter be closed without prosecution,'' the attorney general said. ``Furthermore, since the investigation has not produced sufficient evidence to enable me to ascertain that any present employees of the Department of Justice was responsible for the disclosure, I have determined that no termination of employment or other disciplinary action is justified in this matter at this time.'' The leak occurred while Gray was seeking election in the House as majority whip, prompting accusations from Democratic lawmakers that Thornburgh's aides were the source of a political leak. Two weeks after Ms. Braver's broadcast that Gray's office was being investigated, the Justice Department stated that Gray was not a target of the investigation and was cooperating with the probe. Gray, who was elected whip, said the day after the broadcast he had been told by FBI agents from the Philadelphia office in a Memorial Day interview that he was not a target and that they were looking into the possibility that one of his employees held a no-show job. Nothing more has been heard of that investigation. Thornburgh said he wrote to Biden because the Judiciary chairman, at a committee hearing June 2 at which Thornburgh testified, ``raised questions with regard to my concerns over unauthorized disclosure of information.'' Biden said in a statement that Thornburgh wrote him that the department's Office of Professional Responsibility concurred with all conclusions and recommendations of the Criminal Division in the matter. But the senator said committee staff members had checked with the Office of Professional Responsibility and though that office had been consulted, ``It has never seen the criminal division report or any of its conclusions, and therefore could not have an has not concurred in those conclusions.'' Normally, the Office of Professional Responsibility would be responsible for recommending disciplinary action against department employees. Thornburgh's spokesman, David Runkel, said, ``I don't know whom Sen. Biden or his staff has been talking to, but that statement is clearly at odds with what the attorney general was told by the criminal division. The head of the Office of Professional Responsibility, Michael E. Shaheen, does not have a listed telephone number. Thornburgh told the senator that 11 FBI agents devoted approximately 385 days to the investigation, interviewing members of the U.S. attorney's office in Philadelphia, the Philadelphia division of the FBI, FBI headquarters, the criminal division of the Justice Department and the attorney general's office. He said about 30 other persons were also interviewed, including members of Congress, aides to Gray, confidential sources and several reporters. Ms. Braver ``declined to be interviewed or otherwise cooperate with this investigation,'' he said. Gray said in a statement from Philadelphia: ``The failure of this investigation raises the white flag of surrender to those in the Department of Justice who use false leaks to defame innocent citizens. The leaks in this case were designed to harm me, but their real victim was the integrity of our criminal justice system.'' CBS said Ms. Braver was on vacation.
